Key Arguments: The legislation would restrict access to information, limiting the ability to make informed choices.
Restricting information removes objective criticism and open debate.
People should have the freedom to access all information and make their own decisions.
There is concern about who decides what is classified as misinformation, suggesting it could be influenced by financial interests.
The analogy of a library is used to argue that people can discern between different types of information, including fiction.
Main Themes: Skepticism about authority and control over information
Notable Quotes: How is anyone able to make an informed choice on any subject matter without being able to research all sides.
What classifies something as misinformation? All information can be classed as misinformation by whom ever pays the highest price to have that information classified as such.
We should have access to all information so we can make our own choice on what is good for us.
